item.title: Ticket #6983 (Cannot Edit Posts) created
item.dc:creator: gbweathersby
item.description:
I am in the process of transferring a blog to a new install of wordpress 2.5 on godaddy. It was working fine. Then all of a sudden I began getting the following error whenever I try to edit a post.

Warning: call_user_func_array(): First argumented is expected to be a valid callback, 'wp_htmledit_pre' was given in /home/content/g/b/w/gbweathersby/html/leading-execution/wp-includes/plugin.php on line 163

I have tried looking in the forums and support areas but could find nothing. So I am guessing it is something I did. Short of starting over I am at a loss.

If you could help I would be greatly appreciative.

Regards,

Geoff

fixed:

reseting to 2.5 version. Infact, It'd be better to seek help in the support forums, or open a ticket which refers to your problem specifically. This ticket was for the removal of the cache, which doesnt affect you. (Assuming you're running an uptodate version of WordPress)

item.title: Ticket #5570 (Remove default persistent object cache) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
includes/function.php still makes serialization calls, throwing a PHP memory error when it runs out of space.

That'd be due to options being set/updated, they *have* to be serialised if they're not a simple string. So by the sounds of it, Something is storing rather large options which overflows the memory limits?

item.title: Ticket #6979 (Flash Player 10 breaks the media uploader) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
As the Flash uploader is a External application, They'll release a new release to stay up to date, I do not believe WordPress itself will have to change anything (Other than to include the latest release in the next WP release)

​http://swfupload.org/forum/generaldiscussion/532

I've installed the FP 10 beta and found that SWFUpload does not work. We'll be working on this and will probably have another v2 release before Flash Player 10 is released.

item.title: Ticket #6979 (Flash Player 10 breaks the media uploader) updated
item.dc:creator: zamoose
item.description:
Except it's a beta release. No sense spinning any wheels until

  1. 10 is actually released
  2. We have evidence that the final is messing up the uploader
  3. We can verify that the changes will not affect users staying at Flash 9

item.title: Ticket #6979 (Flash Player 10 breaks the media uploader) updated
item.dc:creator: tcloer
item.description:
Replying to zamoose:

Sounds like an Adobe issue, not a WordPress one.

I don't think so. After Flash Player 9 came out, 62% of the installed base upgraded in the first three months. I bet this will happen with FP 10 as well. So maybe someone should at least take a look at the changes in the new version and see if the WordPress uploader could be adapted accordingly...

item.title: Ticket #6978 (Accessing password protected posts though bloglines sends reader ...) created
item.dc:creator: MidoSibira
item.description:
Accessing password protected posts though bloglines sends non-admin reader directly to admin dashboard:

1) User selects a feed in bloglines 2) In the bloglines frame the user enters the password for the protected post 3) Wordpress dashboard is loaded in the bloglines frame instead of the protected post

This gives the non-admin user full access to the wordpress blog.

item.title: 6977_fix.patch attached to Ticket #6977
item.dc:creator: minddog

item.title: Ticket #6977 (Undefined indexes for $redirect and $original in redirect_canonical) created
item.dc:creator: minddog
item.description:
To reproduce do a fresh install of wordpress and turn on debug mode. Visit the homepage and you'll see the notices.

Notice: Undefined index: port in <removed>/wp-includes/canonical.php on line 181 Notice: Undefined index: query in <removed>/wp-includes/canonical.php on line 181 Notice: Undefined index: port in <removed>/wp-includes/canonical.php on line 181 Notice: Undefined index: query in <removed>/wp-includes/canonical.php on line 181

To fix this issue, I think we can ignore any extraneous initialization code and suppress the notices with @, as the operation array() !== array() is not affected undefined indexes internally.

Please see my patch for fixing this issue, thanks.

item.title: Ticket #6976 (Warning from uninitalized index args in taxonomy.php wp_get_object_terms) updated
item.dc:creator: minddog
item.description: This is the PHP notice, line #'s may differ: Notice: Undefined property: stdClass::$args in <removed>/wp-includes/taxonomy.php on line 1061

item.title: 6976_fix.patch attached to Ticket #6976
item.dc:creator: minddog

item.title: Ticket #6976 (Warning from uninitalized index args in taxonomy.php wp_get_object_terms) created
item.dc:creator: minddog
item.description: To reproduce the issue, turn on debug mode and do a base installation of wordpress. To resolve this issue of only using args property of a taxonomy object is to check to see if $taxonomy->args has been set before using. The patch attached adds an isset() to the start of an if-statement to let the operation continue and to remove the warning from happening.

item.title: Ticket #6728 (Publishing a new Page creates a Draft) updated
item.dc:creator: iandunn
item.description: Is anyone working on this?

item.title: Ticket #6975 (Blank page after logging in) created
item.dc:creator: iandunn
item.description:
I did a new install of 2.5.1 on Windows 2003, PHP 5.2.0, MySQL 5.0.22.

I start out going to ​http://example.com/wp-admin/ and get redirected to ​http://example.com/wp-login.php?redirect_to= to login, then I enter my username and password and hit submit and it goes to ​http://example.com/wp-login.php, which is blank. If I then manually go to ​http://example.com/wp-login.php or ​http://example.com/wp-admin it takes me to the dashboard just fine.

PHP's display_errors is On, and I'm not getting any errors, just a blank screen.

There are a lot of posts about this on the support forums, but no solid fixes. The only plugin I'm running is Askimet, and the problem happens even when it is deactivated. It happens with the default theme too.

item.title: Ticket #6974 (Delay loading of l10n string files) created
item.dc:creator: mark-k
item.description:
Right now, whenever a load_textdomain is called, the translation file is being loaded into the memory. If someone uses an hardcoded localized theme, it is possible that there will not be even a single translation when a page is viewed, and the CPU and memory used in loading the file are simply wasted.

My suggestion is that load_textdomain will not load the file but just make a list of all the domains and their respective translation files, and only when an actual translation is requested for the domain, the translation file will be loaded.

item.title: Ticket #6904 (Blog by email posts blank in 2.5.1 w/ HTML email) updated
item.dc:creator: nrackliffe
item.description: Cc, Keywords changed

item.title: Ticket #6904 (Blog by email posts blank in 2.5.1 w/ HTML email) updated
item.dc:creator: nrackliffe
item.description:
Keywords, Priority changed

I suspect that the problem lies in this section of wp-mail.php: 

139    if ($content_type == 'multipart/alternative') {
140 	        $content = explode('--'.$boundary, $content);
141 	        $content = $content[2];
142 	        $content = explode('Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable', $content);
143 	        $content = strip_tags($content[1], '<img><p><br><i><b><u><em><strong><strike><font><span><div>');

Gmail sends out HTML mail as a multipart/alternative, however it doesn't have the 'Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable' header. This leaves $content[1] empty, which results in a post with a title, but no body.

A different solution is needed to remove the headers from the multipart message. I tried doing the following and it seems to be working, but there is probably a better way to detect this. 

142 	        $content = explode('\n\n', $content);

A fix to this section of code will probably help most people that are having problems with blank posts coming from email.

item.title: Ticket #6565 (Under WP 2.5, the comments that have been marked as spam by Akismet ...) closed
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
fixed:

​http://dev.wp-plugins.org/changeset/46026

item.title: Ticket #6973 (Serbian Cyrillic letters aren't transcripted to ASCII in URL slugs) created
item.dc:creator: dimadin
item.description:
This is my first ticket, so sorry if I don't make it correctly.

We have some issue with URL slugs when using Serbian Cyrillic script in title. Letters are not converted to ASCII letters, as they are for example in Serbo-Croatian Latin script, so Cyrillic stay in URLs.

We have practice that in URLs Cyrillic is transliterated in Latin and then those non-ASCII Latin letters (š, ž, č, ć, đ) are also converted to Latin (s, z, c, c, dj, respectively).

Is there way that this be implemented, since users either write slugs manually or they even don't use post's titles in permalinks?

item.title: Ticket #6565 (Under WP 2.5, the comments that have been marked as spam by Akismet ...) updated
item.description:
In the meantime ...

In Akismet 2.1.4, change wp-content/plugins/akismet/akismet.php, line 483 from:

$comments = akismet_spam_comments( $current_type );

to

$comments = akismet_spam_comments( $current_type, $page );

(Ref: ​http://www.blogitude.com/2008/05/14/fix-wordpress-25-akismet-214/)

item.title: Ticket #6972 (Spacing for RSS Widget date display) created
item.dc:creator: MtDewVirus
item.description:
When using the RSS Widget if "Display item date?" is checked, the date output is in the form:

<a class='rsswidget' href='​http://domain.com/link/' title=>feed item title</a><span class="rss-date">May 8, 2008</span>

There should be a space between the title and the date.

item.title: Ticket #6971 (plugin variables not available as global in register_activation_hook ...) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
Keywords changed

Unfortunately, Its not something that can be changed easily.

As plugins are included from inside a function(When activated), the variables' scope is that function, not global like it used to be under 2.3.x(i believe).

The solution is to use this code instead: 

global $my_plugin_some_var;
$my_plugin_some_var = "foo";
register_activation_hook(__FILE__, 'my_install_func');
function my_install_func() {
global $wpdb; // wordpress var, this will be fine
global $my_plugin_some_var; // this will not work, the var will have to be re-declared here
....
}

See Also: #5860

However, Once activated, Plugins *area* included in the global scope, so the global keyword is no longer needed, but does no harm.

Suggest closing as wontfix unless theres a possible fix which i cant think of.
